author: mtoda8639
content:
Hey all, I have a question about m-of-n aggregated signature verification in ETH2 (apologies if this is not the correct channel for this type of question)

We use a 2-of-3 multi-signature scheme for our wallets and are working on our ETH2 implementation. It's pretty easy with BLS to aggregate 3 public keys, and similarly to aggregate the 2 signatures. However, I'm not aware of an in-built way to define the signature threshold - it seems that the threshold can only be enforced by the verifier (i.e. check that the aggregated signature is valid for at least 2 of the 3 aggregated pubkeys)

Will ETH2 have a way to define a signature threshold for accounts? Am I missing something and this is actually non-issue?

author: ralexstokes
content: you don't necessarily get more rewards but it is very straightforward to e.g. include attestations from the block at slot S-1 in your slot S and collect the proposer share for the attestations that would have been in both blocks

author: ralexstokes
content: there are a number of issues w/ having the proposer be known in advance and there is some research to make this "leader election" secret

author: ralexstokes
content: i can link you more info on ethresear.ch if you'd like

author: chaserxy
content: validators in general should guard their identity by not associating real name/social media accounts with their public key, and hide their IP using a VPN at minimum, but preferably routing the whole setup through Tor.

author: chaserxy
content: the more validators' (quasi-)identity and location are known, the  more vulnerable the network becomes to sovereign-level attackers

author: chaserxy
content: this includes first shuffling deposit funds through Tornado Cash or a privacy coin

author: ralexstokes
content:
the first thing to be clear is that we use BLS signatures at the consensus layer for the purposes of validators and we won't necessarily use them at the user-level (when and where that comes about -- nothing is stopping a migration to "BLS accounts" but that likely falls under the account abstraction research that is ongoing along w/ the details of the eth1-eth2 merge which also has ongoing discussion ðŸ™‚ )

so then you can talk about threshold schemes for validators where there are several options like "secret shared validators" but i will also point out there are good reasons why the current consensus is to run "simple staking setups" until the software stack matures a bit more overall

author: mtoda8639
content: Ah, interesting - I didn't know that it wasn't intended for user accounts. We are currently working on implementation for the withdrawal key for validators, though - just want to make sure that our 3-aggregated-key withdrawal keys will be withdrawable with signatures from 2 of the keys when the time comes that they can withdraw

author: ralexstokes
content: it is not not intended for user accounts

author: ralexstokes
content: its more that the decision has not been made yet

author: ralexstokes
content: my understanding is that you do the threshold set-up "off chain" so that the withdrawal credential is a commitment to the threshold public key and then any 2 of the 3 member signatures can be used to recreate a validating signature when it is time to withdraw

author: mtoda8639
content: Ah, OK - that would solve my issue. The BLS library we've been using (https://github.com/ChainSafe/bls) doesn't seem to have a way to specify an aggregated key's threshold. Maybe they have only planned for the n-of-n situation. I'll bring this up with them, in that case - Thank you!

author: ralexstokes
content: yeah i actually don't know of a bls library that implements threshold signatures for you

author: ralexstokes
content: if you find one or create it, please share!

author: mtoda8639
content: Will do!
